title: First Meetup
description:
Hi,

We will have our first meeting on the 19.06 starting at 18:30 at Startup Hub.

the agenda for the first meetup:

* introductions
* why js - Raul
* Understanding and measuring web performance - Bogdan Gaza
* Closures and js module pattern based on a refactoring example - Raul
* themes for next meetups

for the refactoring i will take a small piece of code and try to refactor it, also covering closures and the module pattern (that i use a lot :) )

this will lead into a open-dialog part, where we can discuss different approaches.

if you have any samples that we can use, please let me know, we can also consider them for future meetings. maybe it becomes a permanent slot :)

Thanks,

Raul.
talks: Understanding and measuring web performance (Bogdan Gaza)
Closures and JS module pattern based on a refactoring example (Raul)

title: tim.js gathering
description:
Cum spuneam la ultimul meetup, ma gandeam sa facem o iesire "hidratanta" sa ne cunoastem mai bine.

Va rog sa folositi link-ul urmator sa votati zilele in care ati putea ajunge:
http://doodle.com/fxftpre5hurhm8bh

Am ajuns la concluzia ca nu sunt in stare sa fac legatura intre imaginea care o aveti la profil, si figura fizica. Probabil ca nu sunt singurul care are aceasta problema, asadar ma gandesc ca ar fi timpul sa facem ceva in privinta asta.

Locatia va fi un club privat, pe nume "Alt Club", in Piata Libertatii (fosta Alchimia sau BeerTime).

Ca si ora de inceput as propune ora 19:00, dupa lucru.

title: tim.js Special Event: Angular2
description:
JavaScript is everywhere. And some people argue that Angular is, also, all over the place. We think it's not. Yet. But will it?

AngularConnect, the biggest and meanest Angular conference to date just happened in London. Two of our organisers, Lucian PÄƒcurar and Cassian Lup, were there to witness it all. They're eager to share the awesome new stuff that's ahead in the Angular world, and why not, in the JS universe.

Some hot stuff on the plate:
â€¢ Angular2 (syntax, timeline & migration path)
â€¢ A new Routing Library (we promise it's awesome),
â€¢ Performance (not a myth anymore),
â€¢ ES6 & TypeScript (oh yes we did)
and many more.

Limited seats. Get them while you can!

title: tim.js workshop: JavaScript Citizens
description:
This first workshop dives into the building blocks of the ECMAScript language, explaining in detail each of its 1st class citizens, how they work & why is it so important to understand them.

We will dive into the building blocks of the ECMAScript language, explaining in detail how they work & why is it so important to understand them.

In the last part of the workshop, we will implement a small design pattern that every developer uses daily.

CONTENT

- Intro: short history, JS vs ES;
- Primitives: types, typeof, type casting, falsey values;
- Arrays: literals, stack, queue, filtering, iterating;
- Objects: literals, enhanced literals, property descriptors, json;
- Functions: types, returns, 1st class functions.

WHO IS IT FOR?

â€¢ Beginner & Intermediate JavaScript developers who want to discover the language at a deeper level.

â€¢ Advanced developers, who switched to JavaScript recently and want to understand its mechanics.

WHAT YOU NEED?

- laptop with power-plug
- code editor (optional)- Node.JS 4.0 or greater installed (optional)

HOW TO ATTEND?

To attend this workshop, please RSVP this event.
There are only 18 seats available that will be filled on a first-come, first-served basis.

A deposit of 40 RON (9 EUR) is required, which will cover all expenses, including lunch (vegetarian is also available) & beverages (coffee, juice, water).
talks: Intro: short history, JS vs ES
Primitives: types, typeof, type casting, falsey values
Arrays: literals, stack, queue, filtering, iterating
Objects: literals, enhanced literals, property descriptors, json

title: tim.js workshop: JavaScript Mechanics
description:
Welcome to the second JavaScript workshop, organized by tim.js (http://timjs.ro/).

In this workshop we will address the politics that govern the citizens of ECMAScript. We will cover some fundamental concepts of ES5, while also touching new features introduced since ES6.

CONTENT

- Scope: globals, hoisting, TDZ, blocks;
- Strict Mode: usage, present & future;
- Values vs References: deep equality, cloning;
- Context: this binding, changing context;
- Function arguments: defaults, signatures;

WHO IS IT FOR?

â€¢ Intermediate JavaScript developers who want to discover the language at a deeper level.

â€¢ Advanced developers, who switched to JavaScript recently and want to understand its mechanics.

WHAT YOU NEED?

- laptop with power-plug
- code editor (optional)- Node.JS 4.0 or greater installed (optional)

HOW TO ATTEND?

To attend this workshop, please RSVP this event.
There are only 18 seats available that will be filled on a first-come, first-served basis.

A deposit of 40 EUR is required, which will cover all expenses, including a breakfast croissant, lunch (vegetarian is also available) & beverages (coffee, juice, water).
talks: Values vs References: deep equality, cloning

title: tim.js workshop: JavaScript Neighborhoods
description:
Welcome to the third JavaScript workshop, organized by tim.js (http://timjs.ro/).

This workshop focuses on various ways to organize your code, each with it's own pros & cons. We will cover fundamental ES5 concepts, while also touching some new features added since ES6.

CONTENT

- Spaghetti Code
- Object Literals
- Module Pattern
- Revealing Module Pattern
- Module systems & loaders
- ES6 Modules

WHO IS IT FOR?

â€¢ Intermediate & Advanced JavaScript developers familiar with functions, arrays, objects, scope & context

WHAT YOU NEED?

- laptop with power-plug
- code editor- Node.JS 6.0+

HOW TO ATTEND?

To attend this workshop, please RSVP this event.
There are only 18 seats available that will be filled on a first-come, first-served basis.

A deposit of 40 EUR is required, which will cover all expenses, including a breakfast croissant, lunch (vegetarian is also available) & beverages (coffee, juice, water).

DISCOUNT
If you have attended both previous workshops (Citizens & Mechanics), you have a 25% discount, meaning that you should deposit 30 EUR instead.

title: tim.js meetup 36: How do you "type" JavaScript?
description:
How do you "type" JavaScript?

In the context of having various JavaScript flavors & languages that compile to JS, which offer static typing, the aim of this meetup is to answer a few questions:

â€¢ will static types make us write better code?â€¢ will static types reduce the number of bugs?
â€¢ are dynamic languages suited for "small" projects only?
â€¢ can I mix static & dynamic types?
â€¢ should I switch to a statically typed JavaScript flavor?

To help us answer these questions, we have invited 2 special guests:

â€¢ Radu Marinescu
â€¢ Radu Fericean

Moderator: Andrei Pfeiffer

This meetup will take place in a panel-like format, no presentations. The audience is welcome to contribute to the discussion.

photoAlbum.title: tim.js meetup 36: How do you "type" JavaScript?

talks: Panel discussion about static typing in JavaScript with Radu Marinescu and Radu Fericean (Moderator: Andrei Pfeiffer)

description:

---
Agenda:

âž¡ï¸ Building your first Design System
Anca Spatariu - Senior Frontend Developer Steadforce

âž¡ï¸ The flavors of design
Milena Vlad, Meetup Organizer at Design Club Timisoara & UX/UI designer at 123FormBuilder

---

Talks description:

âž¡ï¸ Building your first Design System

Design systems make everyone's life better, whether we're talking about programmers, designers or maketers. Building one, however, might be scary, when in fact you just need to start somewhere and go from there. This presentation aims to give you the basics and a kick in the right direction.

---

âž¡ï¸ The flavors of design - why should anyone care about them?

Considering the ever changing job titles, continuous confusion, search for design unicorns that fail to appear, and constant belief that we are all artists at heart, I would like to discuss how different & not necessarily good at everything we all are and why that is a good thing.

What is the presentation about?
Raising awareness about the different design roles, goals, capabilities & processes. Highlighting the value we can bring to the teams & projects. Describing what motivates us, drives our decisions and all the aspects that we need to balance.

Why is this relevant?
Itâ€™s an opportunity to discuss things that can improve the designer-developer collaboration, by removing assumptions & aligning expectations; as well as facilitate communication by speaking in terms that we all understand & care about.

---

NOTE: We are always looking for speakers, so please send us your proposals.

title: tim.js meetup #67
description:
We're so happy we got the chance to meet up in person at our last gathering. We hope you'll join us again this month, for the first presentations in what seems like forever.

We'll meet at Visma Software this time. To ensure that everyone stays healthy, we've taken all the precautions and we limited the number of attendees to just 30. Hurry up and grab your spot. ðŸ™‹â€â™€ï¸ðŸ™‹â€â™‚ï¸ðŸ™‹

Here's the agenda:

---

âž¡ï¸ Sharing code at runtime using module federation
Adrian FÃ¢ciu - Frontend Developer @wevideo

âž¡ï¸ Simple vs. Easy
Andrei Pfeiffer - Freelance Code Designer

---

â„¹ï¸ Sharing code at runtime using module federation

We usually share code by publishing NPM modules, using micro frontend frameworks or other similar options. In this talk, we are going to look at module federation and how multiple builds can form a single application. A short practical demo will be included along with discussions about use cases to better understand when and where we might want to use it.

â„¹ï¸ Simple vs. Easy

Simple solutions usually require a lot of effort during their usage, but they also provide a high level of control. Complex solutions are usually easy to use, but retain the control for themselves. This theory applies both at high-level architecture and also at low-level, day-to-day code design.

We'll explore different methods for tackling software complexity, by deeply understanding our users and deciding where to place the control: in the implementation, or in the consumer.

---

NOTE: We are always looking for speakers, so please send us your proposals at **contact@timjs.ro**.
talks: Sharing code at runtime using module federation (Adrian FÃ¢ciu)

There are several popular (JavaScript) frameworks for building web applications. They mostly come as single-page apps, server-side rendered or static site generated. We will briefly look at how these patterns work and how Remix gets some of the best ideas from them.

title: tim.js meetup #76
description:
Hello Timisoara JavaScript-ers,

For the February meetup, we'll regroup again at **Doctari Group Technologies**, in Iulius Town, UBC0 building, on the 14th floor.

Here's the agenda for this meetup:

\-\-\-
**1ï¸âƒ£ Component Driven Development with Storybook**
ROBERT TODEA - Software Engineer @ Ladders

**2ï¸âƒ£ FullStack: The Way of GraphQL**
CIPRIAN CABA - VP of Engineering @ 7879
\-\-\-

**1ï¸âƒ£ Component Driven Development with Storybook**
Writing simple and maintainable UI components in React can be tricky, when everything is for grabs. There is nothing preventing us from calling backend APIs, browser APIs and third party APIs and thus adding extra layers of complexity to our UI components. Creating our components as if they are part of a component library can help us.

Storybook is one tool to achieve component driven development.
We will explore Storybook installation & configuration, common and advanced use cases, and third-party integrations (e.g. visual regression testing).

**2ï¸âƒ£ FullStack: The Way of GraphQL**
Let's see how we can leverage the power of GraphQL to provide seamless and performant access to the data layer.

We will explore a tech stack that promises to offer a robust and scalable solution that combines the best of both TypeScript and GraphQL, delivering a truly modern and efficient fullstack experience.

\-\-\-
NOTE: We are always looking for speakers, so please send us your proposals at **contact@timjs.ro**.
talks: Component Driven Development with Storybook (Robert Todea)
FullStack: The Way of GraphQL (Ciprian Caba)

title: tim.js meetup #87
description:
Hello scripters,

Time to meet again! This time we're gathering at our friends at Haufe Group for two presentations:

1ï¸âƒ£ **SRP vs OCP vs ISP**
\-\- Andrei Pfeiffer

In this talk, we'll focus on 3 of the SOLID principles: SRP (the Single Responsibility Principle), OCP (the Open-Closed Principle), and ISP (the Interface Segregation Principle). While there are clear differences between the 3, they all share the same solution, which is the reason why we explore them together.

We'll see when each of the 3 principles are usually violated, what are the potential problems, how to identify them, and last but not least, how to solve them. No slides, just code and practical examples.

2ï¸âƒ£ **Introduction to WebRTC**
\-\- Robert Todea

In this tech talk, we'll explore the fundamentals of WebRTC, a powerful protocol that enables seamless audio, video, and data exchange directly between browsers. Discover how WebRTC revolutionizes online interactions, making way for innovative applications.

Key Points:
(1) Understanding WebRTC: What it is, its core components, and how it establishes peer-to-peer connections.
(2) The Power of Real-Time: Explore exciting use cases ranging from video conferencing and live streaming to online gaming and collaboration tools.
(3) Scaling with MediaSoup: Learn how MediaSoup, a flexible server-side framework, allows you to build complex, large-scale WebRTC applications with advanced features.

title: tim.js meetup #89
description:
Hello javascripters, it's time to meet up again. This time, our host will be Haufe Group. Here's the agenda:

**1ï¸âƒ£ Schema Driven Development**
Ciprian Caba

Do you ever grow tired of managing types, data models, database migrations, runtime validations, api endpoints, openapi schemas? What if there was a better way to manage them so you can actually focus on functionality rather than chores?

Letâ€™s build a simple app and explore how using one single source of truth can make everything better

**2ï¸âƒ£ Modern HTTP Streaming using Web Standards**
Andrei Pfeiffer

Few things are more annoying than waiting for a heavy webpage to load and not seeing any visual progress. Using async requests, we can lazy load the heavy content, displaying the rest of the page to the user sooner and introducing visual indicators to suggest loading progress. However, since serving the initial page is the serverâ€™s job, weâ€™ll analize various methods to place the control back in the server regarding initial page rendering. Weâ€™ll examine how popular frameworks perform SSR Streaming, but also showcase a novel proof of concept using Declarative Shadow DOM to load webpages progressively, out of order, and without JavaScript.

This talk is a fully hands-on demo, exploring multiple approaches to loading heavy content on Server-Side Rendered webpages. The demo includes minimal complexity, using only Express.js and native APIs. No frameworks, no libraries, just vanilla code for everyone to understand. However, this talk is not limited to Node.js. Everything weâ€™ll cover equally applies to any server-side programming language.

***

*We're always looking for new speakers. [Apply here](https://yzunr6agkag.typeform.com/to/ehGtISsK?typeform-source=www.meetup.com) to speak at one of our future meetups.*

description:
Hello javascripters, after the summer break, we're back in business. This time we'll see you at rankingCoach where we're kicking it off with an awesome presentation:

**Automated testing: from isolation to full integration**
*Andrei Pfeiffer*

I started writing automated tests a decade ago, around 2013. At that time, QUnit was the popular testing framework for JavaScript. Soon after that, Jasmine and Karma took over the front-end scene, while Mocha, Chai, and Sinon were the preferred choices for Node.js. On the other hand, regarding end-to-end full system tests, Selenium was reigning supreme.

Nowadays, I'm using a totally different toolkit. In this talk, I'll go over the tools, practices, and philosophies I currently use to write automated functional tests, covering unit, integration, and end-to-end tests as well.

title: tim.js meetup #92
description:
Hello JavaScripters,

It's time for us to meet again. This time, our host will be 3Pillar Global. Here's the agenda:

\*\*\*

**Github Copilot in React Development**
Rares Portan, Tech Lead @ 3Pillar Global
Mihnea Lungu, Senior Software Engineer @ 3Pillar Global

AI.
The world has changed. We programmers feel it more than anyone else.
To survive, we don't compete with AI to do our job. We learn to use the AI to do our job better.

Github Copilot AI is less intrusive than most. It can suggest code snippets, take care of boilerplate code, can even explain pieces of code. Pair programming at its finest.

There is a dark side too. From clearly flawed, wrong or ineficient code to subtle bugs, it can do more harm than good in naive hands. Can we do something about it?

**htmx: More than a meme?**
Victor Ionescu, htmx CEO

Without a doubt htmx's irreverent meme-ing made it one of the most hyped new frameworks out there; everybody has heard of it, but is anyone really using it? Is the simple life proposed by htmx actually a step in the right direction for the front-end or is htmx just out of touch with the reality of the JS world?

In this talk we'll get hands-on with some **real** htmx code and see if it's something worth considering. If not, at least there will be memes

description:
Hello JavaScripters,

\*\*\*

**1\. Dependency Management in Modern Web Projects**
\-\- Adrian Faciu\, Principal Engineer @ WeVideo

When you kick off a new project, dependency management is often the last thing on your mind. But as your codebase grows, youâ€™ll start bumping into issues like conflicting versions, missing dependencies, and security concerns. If you decide to move into a workspace or monorepo setup, dependency management becomes even more complex.

Letâ€™s explore some practical solutions and strategies for tackling these challenges, along with some popular tools that can improve your workflow.

**2\. The code etymologist**
\-\- Andrei Pfeiffer\, Platform Engineer @ Smilecloud

In ancient times, knowledge was passed down through word of mouth, like an endless game of telephone where details changed with each retelling. Without a written record, information was often distorted or lost. This talk draws a parallel to software teams that work without documentation. Just like etymology traces the origins of words, documentation preserves history, accuracy, and meaning in code, ensuring that everyone shares a common understanding.
